Detailed Description

Algorithms for using Connectors representing changes to a BoxLevel.

MappingConnectorAlgorithm objects check and apply mappings.

Member Enumeration Documentation

void SAMRAI::hier::MappingConnectorAlgorithm::modify ( Connector &  anchor_to_mapped,
Connector &  mapped_to_anchor,
const Connector &  old_to_new,
const Connector &  new_to_old,
BoxLevel *  mutable_new = 0,
BoxLevel *  mutable_old = 0 
) const

Most general version for modifying Connectors using mapping Connectors. Modification is the changing of existing Connectors when boxes in a BoxLevel changes according to specified mapping connectors.

The change is represented by a the mapper old_to_new and its transpose new_to_old. The Connectors to be modified are anchor_to_mapped and mapped_to_anchor, which on input, go between a anchor (not mapped) BoxLevel and the old BoxLevel. On output, these Connectors will go from the anchor box_level to the new box_level.

 Input:

                                    (anchor)
                                   ^ /
                                  / /
              mapped_to_anchor-> / /
                                / / <--anchor_to_mapped
                               / v
 mapped box_level:           (old) ---------> (new)
                                   <---------


 Output:

                                    (anchor)
                                          \ ^
                                           \ \
                                            \ \ <-mapped_to_anchor
                        anchor_to_mapped --> \ \
                                              v \
                                              (new)

The BoxLevels before and after the mapping are represented by the base and head of the mapping. No BoxLevel is modified, other than the "mutable" BoxLevels in the argument.

An important constraint in the old_to_new Connectors is that this method cannot handle multiple maps at once. For example, it cannot map box J to box K and at the same time map box I to box J. Box J in the old box_level and box J on the new box_level are considered entirely different boxes.

After modifying, the output Connectors that had referenced old BoxLevels will be reset to reference the new BoxLevel. This is the end of the modify operation.

The following "in-place" modification is provided for users' convenience. Often times, the "new" level is a temporary object and users often reset output equivalent to:

  • old = new
  • reset Connectors using old in place of new.
The modify methods support these optional steps as follows: If mutable versions of some BoxLevel are given, the output Connectors can be reset to reference these versions instead.

If mutable_new points to the old BoxLevel and mutable_old points to the new, then do an in-place switch as follows:

  • Swap the mutable_old and mutable_new BoxLevels.
  • Use mutable_old (which actually the new BoxLevel after the swap) as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors. Otherwise:
  • If mutable_new is non-NULL, set it equal to new and use it as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors.
  • If mutable_old is non-NULL, set it equal to the old BoxLevel.
Parameters:
[in,out] anchor_to_mapped Connector to be modified. On input, this points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in,out] mapped_to_anchor Reverse (transpose) of anchor_to_mapped. points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in] old_to_new Mapping from the old BoxLevel to the new BoxLevel. The width of old-->new should indicate the maximum amount of box growth caused by the change. A value of zero means no growth.
[in] new_to_old Reverse (transpose) of old_to_new.
[in,out] mutable_new See comments.
[in,out] mutable_old See comments.
Precondition:
(&old_to_new.getBase() == &new_to_old.getHead()) && (&old_to_new.getBase() == &anchor_to_mapped.getHead()) && (&old_to_new.getBase() == &mapped_to_anchor.getBase())

&anchor_to_mapped.getBase() == &mapped_to_anchor.getHead()

&old_to_new.getHead() == &new_to_old.getBase()

anchor_to_mapped.isTransposeOf(mapped_to_anchor)

new_to_old.isTransposeOf(old_to_new)

anchor_to_mapped.getParallelState() == BoxLevel::DISTRIBUTED

void SAMRAI::hier::MappingConnectorAlgorithm::modify ( Connector &  anchor_to_mapped,
Connector &  mapped_to_anchor,
const Connector &  old_to_new,
BoxLevel *  mutable_new = 0,
BoxLevel *  mutable_old = 0 
) const

Version of modify requiring only the forward map and allows only local mappings.

This version does not require the reverse mapping, but the mapping must be totally local, e.g. old_to_new must contain no remote neighbor.

 Input:

                                    (anchor)
                                   ^ /
                                  / /
              mapped_to_anchor-> / /
                                / / <--anchor_to_mapped
                               / v
 mapped box_level:           (old) ---------> (new)


 Output:

                                    (anchor)
                                          \ ^
                                           \ \
                                            \ \ <-mapped_to_anchor
                        anchor_to_mapped --> \ \
                                              v \
                                              (new)

The modify methods support these optional steps as follows: If mutable versions of some BoxLevel are given, the output Connectors can be reset to reference these versions instead.

If mutable_new points to the old BoxLevel and mutable_old points to the new, then do an in-place switch as follows:

  • Swap the mutable_old and mutable_new BoxLevels.
  • Use mutable_old (which actually the new BoxLevel after the swap) as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors. Otherwise:
  • If mutable_new is non-NULL, set it equal to new and use it as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors.
  • If mutable_old is non-NULL, set it equal to the old BoxLevel.
Parameters:
[in,out] anchor_to_mapped Connector to be modified. On input, this points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in,out] mapped_to_anchor Reverse (transpose) of anchor_to_mapped. points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in] old_to_new Mapping from the old BoxLevel to the new BoxLevel. The width of old-->new should indicate the maximum amount of box growth caused by the change. A value of zero means no growth.
[in,out] mutable_new See comments.
[in,out] mutable_old See comments.
Precondition:
(&old_to_new.getBase() == &old_to_new.getBase()) && (&old_to_new.getBase() == &anchor_to_mapped.getHead())

&anchor_to_mapped.getBase() == &mapped_to_anchor.getHead()

anchor_to_mapped.isTransposeOf(mapped_to_anchor)

anchor_to_mapped.getParallelState() == BoxLevel::DISTRIBUTED

void SAMRAI::hier::MappingConnectorAlgorithm::modify ( Connector &  anchor_to_mapped,
const Connector &  old_to_new,
BoxLevel *  mutable_new = 0,
BoxLevel *  mutable_old = 0 
) const

Version of modify requiring only the forward map and does not set the Connector from the mapped BoxLevel back to the anchor BoxLevel.

This version does not require the reverse mapping, but the forward mapping must be totally local, e.g. old_to_new must contain no remote neighbor.

This version does not update the Connector from the mapped box_level back to the anchor box_level. (This is implicit in the fact that mapped_to_anchor is absent from the interface.)

 Input:

                                    (anchor)
                                     /
                                    /
                                   /
                                  / <--anchor_to_mapped
                                 v
 mapped box_level:           (old) ---------> (new)


 Output:

                                    (anchor)
                                          \
                                           \
                                            \
                        anchor_to_mapped --> \
                                              v
                                              (new)

If mutable_new points to the old BoxLevel and mutable_old points to the new, then do an in-place switch as follows:

  • Swap the mutable_old and mutable_new BoxLevels.
  • Use mutable_old (which actually the new BoxLevel after the swap) as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors. Otherwise:
  • If mutable_new is non-NULL, set it equal to new and use it as the mapped BoxLevel in the output Connectors.
  • If mutable_old is non-NULL, set it equal to the old BoxLevel.
Parameters:
[in,out] anchor_to_mapped Connector to be modified. On input, this points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in,out] old_to_new Reverse (transpose) of anchor_to_mapped. points to the BoxLevel being mapped.
[in,out] mutable_new See comments.
[in,out] mutable_old See comments.
Precondition:
&anchor_to_mapped.getHead() == &old_to_new.getBase()

anchor_to_mapped.getParallelState() == BoxLevel::DISTRIBUTED

size_t SAMRAI::hier::MappingConnectorAlgorithm::findMappingErrors ( const Connector &  connector,
MappingType  map_type = UNKNOWN 
) const

Check if the Connector has a valid mapping.

This function can be called prior to calling modify(). It is intended to check the Connector that is the old_to_new argument in modify() to determine if it has a valid mapping. In other words, it checks to see if the mapping can be used in modify() without logic errors. It does no other checks.

Parameters:
[in] connector 
[in] map_type LOCAL means assume the mapping is local. NOT_LOCAL means the mapping is not local. UNKNOWN means find out whether the map is local or not (communication required) and act accordingly.
Returns:
number of errors found.

void SAMRAI::hier::MappingConnectorAlgorithm::assertMappingValidity ( const Connector &  connector,
MappingType  map_type = UNKNOWN 
) const

Run findMappingErrors and abort if any errors are found.

Parameters:
[in] connector 
[in] map_type LOCAL means assume the mapping is local. NOT_LOCAL means the mapping is not local. UNKNOWN means find out whether the map is local or not (communication required) and act accordingly.
